results.adx_keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Defense and Military Forces;Espionage and Intelligence Services;Palestinians;Terrorism;Netanyahu, Benjamin;Shin Bet;Hamas;Israel;Gaza Strip
results.byline: By Ronen Bergman, Mark Mazzetti and Maria Abi-Habib
results.title: How Years of Israeli Failures on Hamas Led to a Devastating Attack
results.abstract: Israeli officials completely underestimated the magnitude of the Oct. 7 attacks by Hamas, shattering the country’s once invincible sense of security.

media.caption: Before the attack by Hamas on Oct. 7, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and top Israeli security officials believed the greatest threats to Israel were Iran and Hezbollah.
media.copyright: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Palestinians;Writing and Writers;Israel-Gaza War (2023- );War and Armed Conflicts;Keret, Etgar;Netanyahu, Benjamin;Hamas;Israel
results.title: ‘I Feel a Human Deterioration’
results.abstract: The Israeli writer Etgar Keret has spent the last few weeks trying to make sense of the violence and loss around him. So far, he can’t.

media.caption: Etgar Keret at home in Tel Aviv. “I think that this entire nation is going through PTSD,” he says.
media.copyright: Ofir Berman for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Flowers and Plants;Gardens and Gardening;Insects;Butterflies and Moths;Content Type: Service
results.title: If You Plant Milkweed, They Will Come. (And Not Just the Butterflies.)
results.abstract: These underappreciated plants attract a “hungry throng” of beneficial insects. They’re not bad to look at, either.

media.caption: Common milkweed (Asclepias syriaca), the most widespread milkweed east of the Rocky Mountains, can colonize disturbed sites. But most of the more than 90 recognized North American species have a harder time making themselves at home.
media.copyright: Illustration by Beverly Duncan, from “The Milkweed Lands” by Eric Lee-Mäder, used with permission from Storey Publishing

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Television;Actors and Actresses;Perry, Matthew
results.byline: By Alex Traub and Matt Stevens
results.title: Matthew Perry, Star of ‘Friends,’ Is Dead at 54
results.abstract: He was known for playing the sarcastic but lovable Chandler Bing and for his struggles with drugs and alcohol, which he chronicled in a memoir.

media.caption: Matthew Perry, who played Chandler Bing in the television series “Friends,” also appeared in numerous other television shows and movies. He had publicly struggled with drinking and drug use for decades.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Actors and Actresses;Television;Comedy and Humor;Moll, Richard (1943-2023)
results.title: Richard Moll, Towering Bailiff on ‘Night Court,’ Dies at 80
results.abstract: His career spanned more than four decades, but he was best known for playing the imposing but lovable Bull Shannon on the long-running NBC sitcom.

media.caption: Richard Moll, right, as the bailiff Bull Shannon in a 1991 episode of the sitcom “Night Court.” Also pictured are, from left, Charles Robinson as the court clerk Mac, Cathy McAuley as Bull’s bride-to-be and Paddi Edwards as Bull’s mother.
media.copyright: Alice S. Hall/NBC, via Getty Images

results.adx_keywords: Lewiston, Maine, Shootings (2023);Threats and Threatening Messages;Card, Robert R;Lewiston (Me);Maine
results.byline: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Chelsia Rose Marcius
results.title: Maine Sheriff Says He Sent Statewide Alert About Gunman Last Month
results.abstract: The sheriff said the gunman had made threats against the Army base where he was assigned, prompting an alert to all law enforcement agencies in the state weeks before the mass shooting.

media.caption: Law enforcement officers search a property in Durham, Maine, during the manhunt for the gunman who killed 18 people and wounded 13 on Wednesday. The gunman’s body was found on Friday.
media.copyright: John Tully for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Pumpkins;Autumn (Season);Halloween;Content Type: Personal Profile;Adam Bierton;New York Botanical Garden
results.title: A Professional Pumpkin Carver Spills His Guts
results.abstract: Adam Bierton is allergic to pumpkins, but that doesn’t stop him from carving dozens each fall, the most intricate of which can cost $5,000.

media.caption: A pumpkin carved by Adam Bierton at the New York Botanical Garden, where he has been doing weekend demonstrations since 2018.

results.byline: By Catrin Einhorn and Thea Traff
results.title: The Scientists Watching Their Life’s Work Disappear
results.abstract: Some are stubborn optimists. Others struggle with despair. Their faces show the weight they carry as they witness the impact of climate change.

media.caption: David Obura with finger coral originally from the southwest Indian Ocean.
media.copyright: Thea Traff for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Black People;Race and Ethnicity;United States Politics and Government;Johnson, Mike (1972- );House of Representatives;Republican Party
results.title: On Race, Mike Johnson Says His Views Were Shaped by Raising a Black Child
results.abstract: The new House speaker has kept his oldest son out of the public eye — except when the Republican talks about race.

media.caption: House Speaker Mike Johnson faces new scrutiny for his comments on race, which have sometimes included mention of his son Michael, whom Mr. Johnson says he took in 24 years ago and raised with his wife, Kelly.

results.adx_keywords: Israel-Gaza War (2023- );Stockpiling;Palestinians;Water;Hamas;Gaza Strip;Israel
results.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Maria Abi-Habib
results.title: As Gazans Scrounge for Food and Water, Hamas Sits on a Rich Trove of Supplies
results.abstract: Hamas has spent years stockpiling desperately needed fuel, food and medicine, as well as ammo and weapons, in the miles of tunnels it has carved out under Gaza.

media.caption: Palestinians receiving building materials through tunnels in Southern Gaza in 2011. The network is by now so established that Hamas can manufacture weapons underground, eliminating the need to smuggle them from Egypt.
media.copyright: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

results.title: ‘We Are Overpaying the Price for a Sin We Didn’t Commit’

results.title: I Might Have Once Favored a Cease-Fire With Hamas, but Not Now
results.abstract: Today it is clear to me that Hamas’s power and ability to threaten Israel — and subject Gazan civilians to ever more rounds of violence — must end.

media.caption: The aftermath of an Israeli strike on Gaza City on Oct. 26.

results.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Tiffany May and Claire Fu
results.title: As China Looks to Broker Gaza Peace, Antisemitism Surges Online
results.abstract: China’s state-run media has blamed the United States for deepening the crisis, while perpetuating tropes of Jewish control of American politics.

media.caption: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, and the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, met in Beijing in June. In recent years, China has sought to play a bigger role in the Middle East.

results.byline: By Declan Walsh and Hannah Reyes Morales
results.title: The World Is Becoming More African
results.abstract: Africa has the fastest growing, youngest population of any continent. By 2050, one in four people on the planet will be African. Early tremors of this seismic change are already registering around the world.

media.caption: As the world grays, Africa blooms with youth.
media.copyright: Hannah Reyes Morales for The New York Times

results.title: Netanyahu Apologizes After Blaming Security Chiefs for Failure in Hamas Attack
results.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who has not taken responsibility for Israel’s lapses in the Oct. 7 massacre, deleted a social media post in which he had pointed a finger at security agencies.

media.caption: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, left, with Defense Minister Yoav Gallant and Benny Gantz, a member of Israel’s war cabinet, at a news conference in Tel Aviv on Saturday.
